It had its beginnings in 1842 when the East Indians who lived and worked in neighbouring Narasingapuram, Chintadripet, Pudupet and Royapettah sought a church and school close to them.

ngoList.title: Citizen consumer and civic Action Group (CAG)
ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: 1. Demystifying and disseminating laws and policies of city, state and central governments 2. Conducting consumer awareness seminars on critical issues affecting the consumers 3. Conducting workshops and meetings on important issues affecting the citizens 4. Research on key policy issues, using evidence based approach, including conducting pilot studies, primary and secondary data collection and developing on already available research findings

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Electricity Governance in Tamil Nadu

we authored a paper that reviewed various assessment tools that could be used to support organisations, researchers, open data leaders, and global development practitioners in conducting assessments to build capacity of open data initiatives.For the purposes of this paper, we focussed on how assessment tools can be used to provide useful insights into the progress, opportunities, risks and challenges of implementing an open data initiative – whether at the national, regional or city level.

We embarked on a campaign to create awareness about the harmful effects of pesticides in food and thus encouraging consumers and farmers to go organic. The main objectives of the campaign were to create awareness amongst the younger generation on the harmful effects of pesticides.

CAG carried out a pilot study to assess the state of governance in transport on principles of transparency, accountability, capacity and participation in Tamil Nadu. The project’s broad aim was to understand the formal and informal processes undertaken by institutions responsible for shaping and implementing transport policies and plans.

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Society
sourceOfFunds.purpose: CAG has been working on advocating for road safety legislations with Global Road Safety Partnership. The purpose of the project is to advocate for improved road safety through actions directed at state governments and national legislators in three south Indian states. In association with Thozhan, flyers to educate the general public on the importance of wearing helmets, seat belts, etc. were printed and distributed.

CAG joined and took on the responsibility of anchoring the ‘Initiative on Waste, Informal Workers and Chennai’s Future’, a group of civil society organisations, activists, and researchers, that are working towards the adoption of sustainable and inclusive solid waste management practices in Chennai. The Initiative successfully advocated with the CoC to implement a strategy paper on issuing identity cards to waste pickers so as to recognise their occupation and safe-guard their livelihood.

CAG has been working on advocating for road safety legislations with Global Road Safety Partnership (GRSP). The purpose of the project is to advocate for improved road safety through actions directed at state governments and national legislators in three south Indian states.Our focus is influenced by the federal nature of India, where national laws need to be adopted by states through their own legislations and policies that provide the mechanisms to operationalise them at the sub-national level

The overall objective is to contribute to environmental sustainability and good governance of Thermal Power Plants by using collaborative multi-stakeholder approach to address the impact of existing and proposed Thermal Power Plants (TPPs) in India through a combination of information dissemination, evidence-based research, and advisory and advocacy related activities.
Whose rights to the smart city Research Network

The vast majority of plastic waste originates on land, and reaches the oceans because of unsustainable product design and inadequate waste management systems. It is clear that a dramatic intervention is needed, one which demonstrates transformative zero waste systems at the local level and uses data to drive sustainable redesign of production and consumption.

CAG has initiated a project to empower consumers by educating them about various aspects of the electricity sector. Towards this end, CAG has initiated Electricity Consumer Cells (ECCs) in three districts of Tamil Nadu viz; Tiruvallur, Tirunelveli, and Cuddalore in partnership with three consumer organizations. The ECCs work under the guidance of ECC State Electricity Advisors. Also conduct periodic outreach meetings and capacity building programs to train local communities.
This is an initiative to empower local communities on the EIA process. The purpose of the initiative is to contribute to environmental sustainability and good governance.

Indian cities have the challenge of meeting solid waste management needs in the face of rising consumption, crumbling infrastructure, and under-performing service providers. Against this context, greater attention is being paid to the informal sector, which diverts thousands of tons of waste from India’s landfills daily, with a view to leveraging and developing its capacities.The newly issued Solid Waste Management (SWM) Rules, 2016, instructs local bodies to register and include waste pickers

sourceOfFunds.departmentName: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Society
sourceOfFunds.purpose: Since October 2015, CAG has been working on advocating for road safety legislations with Global Road Safety Partnership (GRSP). In the past year, CAG has been regularly communicating with Members of Parliament from the South, particularly Tamil Nadu to discuss and advocate for appropriate amendments to the Motor Vehicles Act. Along with the other partner organisations in India, CAG sent comments to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Transport that was reviewing the Motor Vehicles Amendment

CAG undertook a campaign to encourage and educate farmers on the ease of organic farming and vermicomposting and encourage and educate the younger generation on the importance of organic farming and kitchen/rooftop gardening.In this regard, a vermicompost pit was set up in Thiruvannamalai and organic cultivation of vegetables done in land identified in Thiruvannamalai and in Women’s Christian College, Chennai.Also there were training sessions on vermicomposting and kitchen gardening for farmer

The purpose of the project is to undertake a survey and develop a chapter on Tamil Nadu’s energy sector, which will include adoption of clean power sector policies. The approach of the project is to conduct political economy-based assessments of constituencies, interest groups, and stakeholders in Tamil Nadu. Towards this end, CAG developed a chapter on historical overview on the evolution of electricity subsidies in Tamil Nadu.

Reboot and Wikimedia staff conducted in-depth design research with over 100 diverse users in India and Nigeria; CAG worked with Reboot to undertake the research in India. Based on the findings, we identified opportunities for Wikipedia to grow its reach and impact, including through new features, strategies, and partnerships—and through harnessing the passion and energy of its global community.

CAG has co-authored a book chapter with Dr. David Sadoway, NTU Singapore, in which the authors examine contentious questions about the provision and governance of urban public services, including the use of digital or electronic services (‘e-services’) in India’s cities.

CAG participated in a study to analyse the transport budget in the local municipal corporation’s annual budget of four years (2012-2016). A municipal budget is an important indicator of the direction the city aims to develop in. An analysis of this document would indicate priorities of the local body, types of projects taken to help achieve the set vision and if the intent is aligned with the needs of its residents.

Way Forward Chennai (WFC) is a platform focussed on bringing together individual practitioners and organisations to advocate for inclusive and credible responses to urban disasters by looking at the areas of (a) city planning and development, (b) protection of the natural ecology, (c) disaster preparedness and management, (d) post disaster relief and rehabilitation, and (e) governance. Way Forward Chennai (WFC) is an inclusive and open forum conceived and designed by three core team members
